tei:msContents.tei:summary: Inscription from the sanctuary of Pietrabbondante recording the renovations of the gate and another element of the Temple A, and a donation to the sanctuary by a censor, whose name is lost.

tei:handNote.tei:note: Letters measure 3.7 cm approx in height. Words are separated by dots.

tei:provenance.tei:placeName: Found in close proximity to the temple A

tei:encodingDesc.tei:p: Marked-up according to the EpiDoc Guidelines

Inscription ItAnt Oscan 7 (fac-simile from Pauli 1883: 115. This file is provided by Internet Archive, licensed with a NOT_IN_COPYRIGHT status

tei:note.tei:p: Various interpretations have been proposed over time for this inscription. The most accepted hypothesis dates back to Pauli 1883 and was completed by Planta 1897.

The hypothesis provided by Rix 1993 follows this interpretative tradition and is also accepted by other editors, at least as regards the central section (see Dupraz 2011). However, Pauli's interpretative hypothesis is based on the reconstruction of hypothetical original dimensions of the stone appearing to be incorrect (see La Regina 2021). An alternative hypothesis is provided by Crawford, Imit 2011, even if some differences may occur on specific points (especially integrations and etymological explanations).
The first line probably contained the name and the title of the dedicatee (see La Regina 2021: 295, supplying [10-14 m.t.]).
Many integrations and interpretations have been proposed for líís[.

Most of the proposals concern the recognition of líís[ as an architectural element of the temple, renovated together with the gate ([p]ụ́rtam). Pauli 1883: 110 proposes 'locker room'; Vetter 1953: 109 'doorstep' (~ Lat. limen; see LiLa). La Regina 1966: 274n48 considered it may refer to the metal protection of the gate, of which an archaeological evidence remains; differently, in 2021 he intreprets líís[ as the past participle of a verb (~ Gr. ληΐζομαι 'to get by force'; see Logeion) agreing with the previous word (]ụ́rtam), referring to a lost thing which was then reacquired and donated to the temple (see La Regina 2021: 295).

According to Rix 1993:345, líís[ is the designation of the room or area to which the gate leads and in which (az pú]d) the Samnium (safinim) performs sacrifices/celebrations (sak[arat). La Regina 2021 considers it unlikely for a political entity (the Samnium) to appear as an active subject in a religious action; therefore he proposes to supply safinim sak[úrúm ist] 'the Samnium is sacred'.
Crawford, ImIt 2011 supplies líís[t-?-] and considers it as the name of the gate ([p]ụ́rtam), referring to the name of a community or a place.

The first word of l. 3 has been interpreted in many different ways. Rix and La Regina supply it as a relative pronoun: pú]d, nom./acc. sg. neut., according to Rix 2002; paa]d, abl. sg. fem., according to La Regina 2021. Colonna and Lejeune supply the word as a preposistion: kúntrú]d 'against' according to Colonna 1996, ehtra]d 'outside, out of' according to Lejeune 1972. Crawford, ImIt 2011 does not provide integrations, but claims the word is a verb meaning 'he adorned'.

The first word of l. 4, ]upam is generally supplied as úr]upam 'roof' (hypothesis by Pauli 1883: 111-2, widely accepted by the other editors), although there are some phonetic issues (see Dupraz 2011: 192). Colonna 1996: 126 proposes to recognise in the word a reference to the portico near the temple A, serving as via tecta of the temple.

The antecedent of the demonstrative íak, 'this' (acc. f. sg.), is generally identified in ]upam (see Rix 1993: 344-7: úr]upam íak 'this roof'). On the basis of the position of the element and other considerations, Dupraz 2011: 192n180 suggests that íak is referred to [p]ụ́rtam.

Rix 1993 (following Pauli 1883) supplies the third visible word, úín[ as úín[itú túvtú, i.e. the institution that together with the censors (keenzstur) built (restored, [uupsens]) the door ([p]úrtam) and the roof (úr]upam).

According to Rix 1993 (following Pauli 1883), the role of Maius Maraeus was to have provided the money ([eítiuvad], abl. sg., integration of l. 6) to the institution and the censors (úín[itú túvtú ín]ím keenzstur) for the renovation.

According to La Regina 2009 [2012]: 324 the name of the magistrate, a meddix tuticus, must be integrated as [---ieis . st]aíieis . maraiieís [· med(dikkiai) · túv(tikai)]. La Regina identifies the magistrate with L. Staius Mr.f., or with Cn. Staius Mr. f. Stafidinus, the dedicator of temple A. See also La Regina 2021: 295-6

Over time many additions and meanings have been proposed for the last visible word of l. 7, úmbn[. The syntactic context suggests to interpret it as the verb of the relative clause p]aam essuf úmbn[íted, whose direct object is p]aam (relative pronoun, acc. f. sg.) and the subject is the pronoun essuf. essuf points to Maius Maraeus, whereas the antecedent of p]aam[ has been lost in the gap of l. 6.

Following Pauli 1883, many editors supply [eítiuvad] (abl. sg.) 'money' in the final gap of l. 6, as referent of p]aam[. Rix 1993: 345-7 proposes to consider úmbn[ as a preterite of an old (nasal-)present of the root *op- 'to make, to create' (see Hackstein 2010: 76-8), having a specific meaning of 'to acquire, to earn (money)'. Based on the consideration that Maius Maraeus could have earned such wealth only having been one of the Italic negotiatores in Delos, Pauli/Rix propose to supply [díleí] 'at Delos', at the end of l. 7: [m]aíieís marai⌜í⌝eís [eítiuvad p]aam essuf úmbn[ited díleí '[with the money] of Maius Maraeus, which (= money) himself (= Maius Maraeus) has made (i.e. earned) at Delos' (Pauli 1883 translated the verb as 'dedit [(he) gave]').
Crawford, ImIt 2011 proposes a different meaning: 'to dedicate' (essuf úmbn[ 'he himself dedicated'). No antecedent seems to have been identified for p]aam.
The pronoun esidu[m is the syntactic subject of d]uunated, with fíís[naí] (dat. sg.) 'temple', as indirect object: 'he himself gave [sth] to the temple'.

The referent of esidu[m can rightly be identified in [m]aíieís marai⌜í⌝eís. The direct object of d]uunated may have been lost in the gap. Dupraz 2011: 241 rightly suggests to identify the direct object in p]aam: 'with the money ... later the same (man), as a gift, has given ...'.

The clause is introduced by the disjunctive conjunction a]vt. Dupraz 2011: 241 proposes to interpret it as a coordinating conjunction introducing a second relative clause (with p]aam as direct object also of duunated).

Rix 1993 considers that it is not plausible to determine the nature of the object of duunated from the surviving remains: a]vt pústiris . esidu[m . duuneís] ḍuunated . fíís[naí . -?- 'but later he himself gave the sanctuary [sth]' (Rix translates fíísna- as 'sanctuary', not 'temple'; see Marchese 2007 and Untermann 2000: 282. See also the ItAnt lexicon). Furthermore, according to Dupraz 2011: 225 «esidu[m] is a focalising anaphoric pronoun indicating that the referent of its antecedent is also the correct referent in the relative clause in which esidu[m] appears, and that no other referent is involved, whatever might be expected».
Crawford, ImIt 2011 supplies fíís[nam, acc. sg., direct object of a verb meaning 'to bring' lost in the gap of ItAnt Oscan 9 (see "Conservation").
Because the inscription is fragmentary, the interpretation of lines 10-11 is complex.
Many are the etymological proposals for leígúss, from 'statue' to 'association', and l]úvfríkúnúss (see Untermann 2000: 428 and 818, and the ItAnt lexicon).

Crawford, ImIt 2011 translates [l]úvfríkúnúss fíf[íked as "statues of Liber (?) ... he fashioned", probably incorrectly connecting the verb fíf[íked with Lat. fingō (see LiLa) from PIE *dheiĝh-, instead of relating it to Lat. faciō (see LiLa) from PIE *dheH1 (see IE-Cor), originally 'to place, to collocate' and therefore, with an expansion -k-, 'to do' (see Poccetti 2006; see also Untermann 1993: 465).

Crawford, ImIt: 1156 assumes that the inscriptions ItAnt Oscan 9 and ItAnt Oscan 8 "are likely to form part of the same text" together with this one, composing a long elogium. The three supports would be «part of the cladding of a podium, base or altar».

The textual reconstruction proposed by Crawford, ImIt is not satisfactory and seems to have to be rejected, as it is not supported by material evidence: from a palaeographic point of view, the letters have a different shape, and, according to La Regina 2021: 294, also the supports have different characteristics (see also La Regina 2009 [2012]: 324 and La Regina 2021: 296-8).
La Regina does not reject the hypothesis of joining together ItAnt Oscan 8 and ItAnt Oscan 9.
Crawford, ImIt: 1157 proposes a dating to 125 BC.
